newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Gonzalez under fire for EMU budget silence.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Gonzalez under fire for EMU budget silence.

text.p: Conservative Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar criticised his Socialist predecessor Felipe Gonzalez on Tuesday for deciding to skip the parliament debate on a 1997 budget crucial to Spain's hopes of joining a European currency.

Gonzalez's Socialists and the Communist-led United Left have introduced motions rejecting the budget, but it is guaranteed a safe passage on the combined votes of the ruling conservatives, their Catalan nationalist allies and smaller regional parties.

Aznar and his aides blamed disarray in Socialist ranks for the main opposition party's decision to give the floor to two of its top economic men rather than to Gonzalez in the three-day debate starting on Tuesday (1430 GMT).
"Gonzalez's absence shows the opposition is incapable of providing an alternative," Aznar told reporters.

The Socialist leader's silence could fuel the arguments of foes to his right and to his left who say the same corruption scandals and charges of a "dirty war" on Basque rebels that cost him his job continue to gag him now he is in opposition.
Gonzalez, who ruled Spain for 13 years until May and was the architect of Spain's 1986 entry to the then European Community, rejected the government's criticism as meddling in his party.
"We are the ones who decide our strategy and our participation and we allocate (tasks), not others," he told reporters.

Aznar's ministers hope the austere budget package will allow them to meet stringent European economic and monetary union (EMU) criteria during 1997, the year on which would-be participants in the single currency will be tested for fitness.
The 1997 budget slashes total spending growth to just 1.7 percent by cutting or freezing outlays in all sectors except for pensions, health and regional transfers.
With inflation expected at 2.6 percent next year, it is the toughest budget since Spain's return to democracy in 1975.

Jose Borrell, the Socialists' top representative in the congressional budget committee, said this week his party would present wholesale amendments to the five separate draft laws which make up the budget proposal, effectively rejecting it.
"(The budget) is not credible, it does not define a sustainable strategy and it will not lead us into (EMU)," he told reporters on Monday.
Borrell said the draft budget was based on accounting tricks and one-off measures, such as freezing public sector wages, which would only reduce the budget deficit in the short term.

He said the conservatives' forecasts were unrealistic and that most departments had been under-funded. Borrell was expected to focus on possible gaps in social security financing during his parliamentary appearance on Tuesday.

Gonzalez has been an ardent supporter of EMU all along, but the Socialists argue that if Spain manages to be among a first wave of participants in 1999 on this budget it will be at the expense of employment and of social welfare.

The initial three-day debate of broad opposition amendments to the draft budget will be followed by the submission of amendments to individual articles until October 28. Parliament's budget commission will then write a report and give its opinion, clearing the way for parliamentary approval on November 22.

Although the PP, with 156 seats, is 20 seats short of an absolute majority in parliament, it is assured support from the 16 seats of Catalonia's ruling Convergence and Unity coalition and the four held by the Canary Islands coalition.
